content: I believe I will only be able to attend the first half of today's meeting.
:wave:

Hello everyone,

It's time for the @WG-governance meeting! React/Reply with :wave: to indicate your attendance. You can find the agenda for today on the GitHub project board. I've also listed the active issues below.

  • Organisation Taxonomy
Seems like we have pretty light attendance today.
indeed.
I'm unsure how to proceed as I know @nikomatsakis said they were working on alternative proposal of the org taxonomy based on activity so I'd prefer to hold off on discussing that.
(wave)
It looks like the project board doesn't explain why items are blocked; Nell, would you mind reminding me why the access policy documentation is blocked?
sorry, I'm running 1 more min late
( @BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand) I believe @Pietro Albini said we should off merging it, there was a reason that couldn't be cited publicly as I recall)
Ah, okay; thanks!
OK, I'm here, sorry
OK, so, I can talk a bit about org taxonomy
if we want :)
though I have a somewhat separate topic to throw out there for.. consideration :)

which is that a group of us from core team have been working a bit on the rustconf keynote and there are some parts of it that want to talk about the achievements of governance wg and a bit about "where we're going", and I wanted to discuss it a bit, though maybe not live
(that is, I could put some notes in another topic and see what people think)
(but I'd also be happy to discuss it now)
Rustconf is soon correct?
rustconf is aug 20
but the talk has to be ready much sooner :)
actually @XAMPPRocky where is the project board
https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-governance/projects/5
@nikomatsakis I think we should talk about rustconf thing it seems like it's most time sensitive since at most we'd only have one more meeting to discuss it.

one challenge is that the talk, like most talks, is still under heavy revision and I'm not 100% sure what I'm "asking for", but I guess I'd be interested in what we see as the "achievements" of the group
and maybe our overall trend
Iirc that was nicely summed up in the last meeting
looking for the list
yeah I was going to say
I think that hackmd we made last time is perhaps all I really even need
(deleted)

• The team repository is much more up to date, and includes a lot more groups.
  • Many repositories are using the team repository for their access rights.

  • Many of the teams' membership is now synced automatically with GitHub through the team repository.
    Alumni are now separate recognised at the team level.

  • Landed the Project Group RFC.

  • Have a nearly complete access policy RFC.
https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-governance/blob/master/minutes/2020.07.09.md
yeah, that's actually perfect
There was another one I thought about, which feels half governance and half release, which is the overhaul of forge as a kind of central team wiki.

For "direction", I think it's pretty centered on the org taxonomy discussion; lots of other things tie into that. "What are the Rust project's core units of organization, and how do they relate to each other" is a fundamental question we're trying to answer
Yeah. I'm actually somewhat interested in revising our charter
to try and make it narrower and more precise
but also, I think what's on the website was never updated when we did the kind of "gov wg revamp"
What do you mean by "what's on the website"? I think there's only the team data, or do you mean a blog post?
https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-governance/blob/master/CHARTER.md
Oh on the repo not the rust-lang website, got it :slight_smile:

anyway, I think I agree with @BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand) that the "org taxonomy" is kind of at the herat, that basically our goal is to "define the structure of the rust org", starting by documenting what's there, but also suggesting changes to help correct problems

the one thing I think that has been really challenging for us is how best to interact with other teams, I feel like we should look into doing more "direct outreach", sort of going in and helping to document team procedures by talking to the teams and trying to flesh out what they are
I see this as "the sort of work that a lot of team members don't have much interest in"
and the idea of this team then is to collect people who are interested in it
yeah, the surveys were sort of a start at that, but meeting with folks seems more likely to succeed, if it is clear what info is needed from the teams
but I've felt this tension always of like "is that work that ought to be done by the teams themselves?"
I think referring to the old "governance" RFC is probably appropriate - we're not necessarily overhauling it, but some of the things we're changing haven't really been evaluated since that RFC
side note that I think the "out of scope" section has language that is kind of...unnecessarily hostile
Yeah, I actually had proposed a revision based on the HackMD, but then withdrew it was it was not quite right, and we were discussing that language there

nikomatsakis said:

but I've felt this tension always of like "is that work that ought to be done by the teams themselves?"

in pareticular I feel like as part of compiler/lang team I've been pushing stuff
This one: https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1068-rust-governance.md
but really I'd (a) probably like more help with that because I feel like it's hard work to get everything organized and (b) it feels somehow disconnected from gov wg which seems wrong?

Maybe it's a question of simply having the structures and processes ( like the project team lifecycle, like the taxonomy) that make it possible for teams to do it themselves without it beign a headache
like, if that's not our role :) then what is!
and for teams to stay aligned, and it to be clear what the org is doing

Yeah, there's kind of one goal which is defining the structure as has been said and there's two tasks that need to be completed. Defining the the structure we want to have, and transitioning the existing processes.
anyway, I've prob said this before, sorry if I'm repeating myself. I've been running a bit ragged last few weeks and can't remember what was said and what was not.
and change management does involve engaging with teams
its ok

all that said, I have thoughts about org taxonomy that I'm pretty sure are fresh, since some of them were born from discussion with @ag_dubs a few days back =) so we can turn to that at some point.. but maybe this current topic is fruitful too
if you want to share thoughts you have right now, it is a good time to capture that
perhaps it and this will dovetail together
Sorry for being quiet - turns out if you are focused on the "mentions" section of Zulip rather than the actual topic, you won't see the messages flowing
@nikomatsakis I just want to check do you feel that the Rustconf stuff was appropriately addressed?
I think so --
Okay, just wanted to make sure we didn't get off track.

basically I would summarize something like

  • gov wg has been working on defining core concepts
  • overall goal is to codify our governance structures and rethink some of them to try and address growing pains
there's going to be a bit of a "call to action!" so one of the things will be encouraging folks to get involved
so I guess that stuff I was saying about
Happy to echo the calls to action as I host RustConf :)
"if you're the sort of person who likes thinking about org structure..." is also relevant
but it seemed like nobody disagreed with that
we need to be clear about what folks should be doing before we call to them perhaps? Helping to win folks over and roll out new structures from within teams?
yeah, but
well (a) we have some time and (b) this is more a general thing, and I think we would want to follow up with specific intorust blog posts and the like
which isn't to say we shouldn't discuss (and that's why I was bringing this up)
but I don't think it's blocking the keynote work over new few days or anything
Oh, I thought you already have what you need for the keynote and were moving on to discussing other activities like revising the charter, working on the taxonomy?
yeah
so org taxonomy

nikomatsakis said:

the one thing I think that has been really challenging for us is how best to interact with other teams, I feel like we should look into doing more "direct outreach", sort of going in and helping to document team procedures by talking to the teams and trying to flesh out what they are

I think some of the problem we might run into this is teams being not really sure of what kind of procedures they would want.

I had an interesting conversation with @ag_dubs and I wanted to kind of discuss some of what we were saying and float those ideas here; as a side note, she's been interested in helping to get involved in this discussion, possibly as a regular participant in this group if she can find the time, or maybe "indirectly" if not

XAMPPRocky said:

I think some of the problem we might run into this is teams being not really sure of what kind of procedures they would want.

Yes
so, as a specific example
I recently had to draw up a procedure for the compiler team
that was like "what do you do to add a new compiler option"
honestly, I'm not sure if what I wrote makes sense :)
it's "ok"
but it's an example of a kind of policy that I think does need to be writtten out --
(ah yes, this came up last time, adding a new "x" in various circumstances)
-- and where I think compiler team members have opinions and constraints but aren't that psyched to write it out
but you could imagine like this group talking to some folks, drawing up a proposal, seeking feedback, iterating a bit
and then posting it
Codifying-but-not-dictating seems like the right approach.
(and hopefully then also harmonizing between groups, like maybe clippy or something needs a similar process)
That's what seems most helpful but least intrusive/top-down.
right, I think we've been afraid of dictating,
but we didn't quite have a model for how to actually help except that people come to us
(or something)

@nikomatsakis Thinking on this a bit more maybe the starting point should be helping teams to define a charter? Because there are some teams where what should be policy is pretty unclear at the moment.
yes, that makes a lot of sense to me
like the starting point is probably
well, when we were talking about the taxonomy it was mostly about kinds of groups, what you're describing sounds like kinds of activities
define a charter and what are the subgroups that exist
(and what do they do)
(which of course brings us a bit back to taxonomy)
I could see us actually trying to systematically go team-by-team and work out a charter
I don't think we have those charters anywhere, right?
like, maybe when team was created the RFC had some material
but some teams (e.g., community) don't have any RFC
(I was surprised to see that, I'd forgotten...)
(I went looking for this the other day)
not that we need another "to do" item just yet ;)
And we could see what is consistent among the teams
(best to keep track, I'm noting it) and yes yes!
so let me talk a bit about taxonomy because it seems relevant-ish
(unless anyone has pending comments to finish typing out)

so earlier I had this idea that we should categorize groups by their "duration", so to speak:

  • teams: things that exist in perpetuity, such as maintainance or triage
  • project groups: pursuing some fixed task, like developing a feature, that comes to an end

then in discussion with the compiler team, we talked a bit about categorizing by "activity level" and "how to get involved":

  • notification group -- no agenda or coordination, but you can sign up and get pinged
  • project group -- specific goals and meetings towards that goal .. or something
  • team -- long-running structure
(we never got super precise about what activity level means, as you can see)
seems reasonable
but what @ag_dubs was looking at was sort of combining both of those, in some sense. Looking I guess first at what activities to do we have to perform
(it might be that a given team does many of these)
I don't have her list off hand but it was something like

• designing new things (language features, maybe website, etc)
  • maintaining existing things
  • project management
  • coordination -- i.e., somebody has a request, you route it to someone who can answer it
  • ... I forget this one
(there were 5, I remember that)
(one sec, trying to remember:)
I guess then the idea was that, separately, we have some different structures
which are largely characterized by "how many people and how it functions" ( kind of like activity level )

"activity level" sounds like an important component of membership expectations, which I think is appropriate for a group's charter. I am not sure it belongs in the top-level Rust project taxonomy, though.

we weren't sure the best names for these, but let me toss out some

  • "point person" -- a small number of defined individuals, maybe 2 or 3, not looking for volunteers or anything
  • "project" -- like a working group, membership is largely based on volunteers and who is putting in time, doesn't decide on RFCs
  • "team" -- a full structured team
anyway we can discuss the exact details there but
is "point person" a per-group thing? I.e. each group would have its own point person(s)?
the key insight that I thought was interesting was to say that not all tasks need to be a team, or a group
in some cases, a point person is enough
or even better
ah, so every task would have _at least_ a point person (i.e. someone who's "responsible" for the task), but possibly more?

and what is the right thing for a task depends on

  • the nature of that task -- is it design? coordination?
  • how frequently it occurs -- is it something that arises every once in a while, or all the time?
so I think one example would be that like, one of the roles of the community team is "redirecting mails that arrive at community@rust-lang.org"
this is a clear coordination task, and it probably just wants a small set of fixed people
in part because you want to be able to execute on a given e-mail without any need for "consensus" amongst a larger group
so you kind of just want people who are experienced and know what to do (though it's interesting to think about how to train and replace)
(that's also an activity)
(yes)
(as is "retire or archive outdated stuff . . . anyhow)
this realtes to something I've been thinking about for the compiler team
which is that I've been thinking about trying to define what I called officers (but maybe that terminology is a bit too .. martial? anyway) around specific roles

and the idea was that they would be elected or nominated or chosen somehow to serve fixed terms -- so e.g., there might be a "prioritization lead" etc, anyway, a lot of these roles are kind of "point people"
anyway, ashley also had an interesting chart
it looked sort of like this

role rarely monthly daily
design point person ... ..
stupid markdown
we get the idea (:
anyway I forget the details, but the key idea was that sometimes we might have "too big" of a structure for a given task
how often it happens, who does it
e.g., maybe we created a team, but all we needed was a point person, or a project group, or whatever
and that thus this could be part of the assessment we're trying to make, "how much structure do we really need for this task"?
and similarly, I think then the question of "how do I create a new team" would be something like
• define the task you need to do
well absically it'd be that you build it up, and that we recognize teams more "once they exist"
this comes back to the "organize by activity", I guess
so, the trick is how to add enough structure that coordination is possible
and keeping track of what is going on is possible

anyway I'm not as sure about that part, that was us noodling some at the end, but it's connected to this idea of like "when do you get promoted to position X?" and the answer is "when you're already doing it" (but you do have to define the criteria up front so people know what they're aiming at)
but without creating things that just fossilize

nikomatsakis said:

this is a clear coordination task, and it probably just wants a small set of fixed people

I would have some worry on attracting people to fill these positions if we compartmentalise too much. It will be easy to fill a design role, less so for being the person who redirects email. I think there will still be need to have shared team responsibilities for work that doesn't want to get done.
yeah, that makes sense
I will say that a huge challenge has always been
you want to "call out for volunteers" but it's also sometimes tricky to control who shows up :)
but I think part of this problem arises because we are maybe defining "leads" too early on
i.e., it's particularly hard when you're giving power or authority
I guess that's somewhat different than what you said @XAMPPRocky
Yeah, though it's part of the same problem of "getting the right people."

The thing is, how do teams really come to be? If not with an RFC . . . Or should it always be with an RFC? Sounded like you favored something more informal to start with that then gets officialized and fits into the taxonomy categories discussed?
I think it is through an RFC, but the key question is more "when do you write the RFC"
as a "related example", consider the Arm Tier 1 RFC
which is proposing to add ARM as a Tier 1 target platform
basically that is the culmination of a lot of work
this is kind of interesting, it relates also to the work on staging that I think we've still not quite figured out
i.e., then the question is "how do we decide when to start down the road"
i.e., for language features, how do we decide "we are going to try and design X"
anyway, I think we can figure out to some extent the question of how to create new groups a bit later, maybe

Another example would be the web presence team, which was first made to see if there was any interest and it seems to be going along now and the question I've thought about is when do we have to have RFC for the team?
like, I'm interested in the idea of describing and analyzing what we have, and I suspect that will help answer the question of how to start new things?

XAMPPRocky said:

Another example would be the web presence team, which was first made to see if there was any interest and it seems to be going along now and the question I've thought about is when do we have to have RFC for the team?

yeah, a very good question
it sounds like there's two kinds of work, development tasks and admin tasks, with teams that mostly do one or the other. Is this correct?
I guess I do think RFCs are appropriate but I am torn on it, I don't know when the right time is, and what steps come before the RFC

Val Grimm said:

it sounds like there's two kinds of work, development tasks and admin tasks, with teams that mostly do one or the other. Is this correct?

so, I don't really think that's true
I guess it depends on what you mean by "admin"
in a nontechnical sense
but there's a lot of "metawork" required to make a team function, at least at a certain scale
actually the statement might be true
it may just be that the teams I'm most involved in are exceptions
well, there's website, events, community
(compiler, language design)
Okay time check; We have less than 5 minutes :slight_smile:
those seem to be admin.
woah
I didn't notice the time ;)
Okay, in terms of action items do we want to reach out to leads about helping to make a charter for their team?
sure
well, we need to define what should be in a charter to guide them, or is that already known?
that's a good point
we have our example but even that needs to be adjusted
I think we should not overly parallelize

sounds like we need to break down the agenda a bit for next time. The themes I am hearing are 1) describe the work teams do and 2) the distinction between non-team tasks and team tasks as well as 3) how are teams created and all of this feeding implicitly into 4) what kind of teams should there be
Hmm, yeah.
I think we should start with one or two teams
and all of these feed into 5) what should go into a charter
and 6) when should you change the charter
yeah, so: "describe the work teams do"
maybe that's a nicer way to frame things than "charter", at least to start
which is nontrivial : D
but yes
there are a lot of nested concepts here and lifecycles, so breaking things down more into what do we need to describe would be helpful, right now we are trying to eat an elephant
remind me, we meet every 2 weeks? :)
To nominate one team to reach out to, I've been talking with @Ashley Mannix who has already been doing some of this work for the libs team.
that's a nice example because
the roles there have been changing a bit
ooh, exemplar
e.g., the compiler team has been taking on maintaince (I just cannot spell that word)
(maintenance)
maintainance ? maintainence ?
maintenance, ok, we'll see if I remember it :)
so that team has been taking on maintenance
Okay everyone that concludes our time for the meeting! Have a safe rest of the week!
ok so let's start maybe with compiler + libs ?
I can take a first stab at compiler and then share it around
ok, see you next time
